pillars.title: Clinical Science and Perioperative Care
pillars.definition: All bedside knowledge and actions directly involved in assessing patients, delivering anesthesia, managing airways, providing sedation, regional, postoperative care, and responding to emergencies.
inclusion_tests: Is this about science, physiology, pharmacology, or patient care decisions?
Is this something a clinician does to or for the patient?
Is this about airways, ventilation, hemodynamics, drug administration, or special populations?
exclusion_tests: Workforce models, compensation, scope laws, hospital politics, wellbeing → Other Pillars
Role definitions, scope boundaries, training requirements → Pillar 2
Systems, equipment maintenance, OR operations, IT, infrastructure → Pillar 3
Legal requirements, compliance, malpractice, regulation → Pillar 4
Compensation mechanics, billing, contracts, subsidies, economics → Pillar 5
Education science, research methods, evidence generation → Pillar 6
Career paths, leadership, job markets, workforce dynamics → Pillar 7
Wellbeing, burnout, identity as lived experience, culture → Pillar 8

sub_pillars.title: Foundational Sciences for Anesthesia Practice
sub_pillars.definition: The scientific foundation underpinning all clinical anesthesia practice, including human physiology and pathophysiology, pharmacology and pharmacokinetics, applied anatomy, and the chemistry and physics relevant to anesthesia delivery. This sub-pillar encompasses the basic science knowledge required for understanding drug behavior, physiologic responses, and disease processes that inform clinical decision-making.

branches.title: Physiology of Organ Systems
branches.definition: Normal physiologic function of cardiovascular, respiratory, neurological, renal, hepatic, and endocrine systems as they relate to anesthesia delivery and patient response. Encompasses the baseline understanding required to predict and interpret physiologic changes during anesthesia.
branches.lens: Understanding how the body functions normally to predict anesthetic responses

topic_domains.title: Cardiovascular Physiology
topic_domains.definition: Cardiac cycle mechanics, myocardial oxygen supply and demand, coronary circulation, cardiac output determinants, and vascular tone regulation. The physiologic basis for understanding hemodynamic responses to anesthesia and surgical stress.

topic_domains.title: Respiratory Physiology
topic_domains.definition: Ventilation mechanics, gas exchange, oxygen transport, carbon dioxide elimination, ventilation-perfusion relationships, and respiratory control mechanisms. Foundation for managing oxygenation and ventilation during anesthesia.

topic_domains.title: Neurophysiology and Autonomic Function
topic_domains.definition: Central nervous system function, cerebral blood flow regulation, intracranial pressure dynamics, autonomic nervous system balance, and neuromuscular transmission. Essential for understanding anesthetic effects on consciousness and autonomic responses.

topic_domains.title: Renal Physiology
topic_domains.definition: Glomerular filtration, tubular function, fluid and electrolyte homeostasis, acid-base regulation, and drug elimination pathways. Critical for managing fluid balance and understanding pharmacokinetic alterations.

topic_domains.title: Hepatic Physiology
topic_domains.definition: Hepatic blood flow, drug metabolism pathways, synthetic function, and bile production. Foundation for understanding drug biotransformation and coagulation factor production relevant to anesthesia.

topic_domains.title: Endocrine Physiology
topic_domains.definition: Hypothalamic-pituitary axes, adrenal stress response, thyroid function, glucose regulation, and calcium homeostasis. Understanding hormonal responses to surgical stress and anesthesia.

topic_domains.title: Hematologic Physiology
topic_domains.definition: Coagulation cascade, platelet function, fibrinolysis, oxygen-carrying capacity, and transfusion physiology. Basis for managing bleeding, anticoagulation, and blood product administration.

branches.title: Pathophysiology and Coexisting Disease States
branches.definition: How acute and chronic disease processes alter normal physiology and impact anesthetic risk, drug handling, and perioperative management. Covers the pathophysiologic basis of conditions commonly encountered in surgical patients.
branches.lens: Understanding how disease modifies physiologic reserve and anesthetic approach

topic_domains.title: Cardiovascular Disease Pathophysiology
topic_domains.definition: Coronary artery disease, heart failure, valvular disease, arrhythmias, and hypertension as they alter anesthetic risk and management. Understanding how cardiac pathology modifies hemodynamic responses and drug effects.

topic_domains.title: Pulmonary Disease Pathophysiology
topic_domains.definition: Obstructive and restrictive lung diseases, pulmonary hypertension, and sleep-disordered breathing affecting anesthetic management. How respiratory pathology alters ventilation strategies and perioperative risk.

topic_domains.title: Neurologic Disease Pathophysiology
topic_domains.definition: Cerebrovascular disease, seizure disorders, neurodegenerative conditions, and neuromuscular diseases relevant to anesthesia. Understanding how neurologic conditions affect anesthetic selection and monitoring requirements.

topic_domains.title: Renal Disease Pathophysiology
topic_domains.definition: Acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and electrolyte disorders affecting drug handling and fluid management. How renal impairment alters pharmacokinetics and perioperative fluid strategies.

topic_domains.title: Hepatic Disease Pathophysiology
topic_domains.definition: Cirrhosis, portal hypertension, hepatic encephalopathy, and coagulopathy of liver disease. Understanding altered drug metabolism, synthetic dysfunction, and hemodynamic changes in liver disease.

topic_domains.title: Endocrine and Metabolic Disease Pathophysiology
topic_domains.definition: Diabetes mellitus, thyroid disorders, adrenal insufficiency, and pheochromocytoma as they impact perioperative care. Managing hormonal imbalances and metabolic derangements during anesthesia.

topic_domains.title: Hematologic Disorders Pathophysiology
topic_domains.definition: Coagulopathies, anticoagulant effects, anemia, and hemoglobinopathies affecting surgical bleeding and oxygen delivery. Understanding bleeding risk assessment and transfusion thresholds.

topic_domains.title: Obesity and Nutritional Pathophysiology
topic_domains.definition: Physiologic changes of obesity including respiratory mechanics, cardiovascular effects, and pharmacokinetic alterations. Managing the metabolically complex patient and understanding malnutrition effects on healing.

branches.title: Pharmacology of Anesthetic Agents
branches.definition: Mechanisms of action, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and drug interactions for all agent classes used in anesthesia practice including inhalational agents, intravenous anesthetics, opioids, neuromuscular blocking agents, local anesthetics, and adjuncts.
branches.lens: Understanding drug behavior to optimize agent selection, dosing, and timing

topic_domains.title: Inhalational Anesthetic Pharmacology
topic_domains.definition: Uptake, distribution, and elimination of volatile agents; MAC concepts; organ system effects of sevoflurane, desflurane, isoflurane, and nitrous oxide. Understanding potency, solubility, and clinical selection of inhaled anesthetics.

topic_domains.title: Intravenous Anesthetic Pharmacology
topic_domains.definition: Pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of propofol, etomidate, ketamine, and emerging agents like remimazolam. Mechanism of action, context-sensitive half-times, and clinical applications for induction and maintenance.

topic_domains.title: Opioid Pharmacology
topic_domains.definition: Receptor pharmacology, pharmacokinetics of fentanyl, sufentanil, remifentanil, morphine, and hydromorphone. Understanding equianalgesic dosing, context-sensitive effects, and opioid-related adverse effects.

topic_domains.title: Neuromuscular Blocking Agent Pharmacology
topic_domains.definition: Depolarizing and non-depolarizing agent mechanisms, onset and duration profiles, metabolism pathways, and factors affecting blockade. Succinylcholine, rocuronium, vecuronium, and cisatracurium clinical pharmacology.

topic_domains.title: Local Anesthetic Pharmacology
topic_domains.definition: Mechanism of nerve blockade, structure-activity relationships, pharmacokinetics, and systemic toxicity of amides and esters. Understanding potency, duration, differential blockade, and maximum doses.

topic_domains.title: Sedative and Anxiolytic Pharmacology
topic_domains.definition: Benzodiazepine pharmacology, dexmedetomidine mechanisms and applications, and the sedation continuum. Clinical use for anxiolysis, sedation, and adjunctive anesthesia.

topic_domains.title: Cardiovascular Drug Pharmacology
topic_domains.definition: Vasopressors, inotropes, vasodilators, antihypertensives, and antiarrhythmics used in anesthesia practice. Mechanism-based selection and dosing for hemodynamic management.

topic_domains.title: Reversal Agents and Antagonist Pharmacology
topic_domains.definition: Sugammadex, neostigmine, flumazenil, naloxone, and other antagonists. Mechanisms of reversal, dosing strategies, and clinical indications for pharmacologic antagonism.

branches.title: Applied Anatomy for Anesthesia Practice
branches.definition: Anatomical structures and spatial relationships essential for airway management, regional anesthesia techniques, vascular access, and understanding surgical positioning effects. Emphasizes clinically relevant anatomy over comprehensive anatomical study.
branches.lens: Spatial and structural understanding for procedural success and patient safety

topic_domains.title: Airway Anatomy
topic_domains.definition: Upper and lower airway structures, anatomic predictors of difficult intubation, and variations affecting airway management. Nasal, oral, pharyngeal, laryngeal, and tracheal anatomy essential for airway interventions.

topic_domains.title: Neuraxial Anatomy
topic_domains.definition: Vertebral column, spinal cord, meninges, epidural space, and cerebrospinal fluid compartments. Surface landmarks, dermatomes, and anatomic considerations for spinal and epidural techniques.

topic_domains.title: Upper Extremity Peripheral Nerve Anatomy
topic_domains.definition: Brachial plexus organization, individual nerve courses, and sonographic appearance. Anatomic basis for interscalene, supraclavicular, infraclavicular, and axillary approaches.

topic_domains.title: Lower Extremity and Trunk Peripheral Nerve Anatomy
topic_domains.definition: Lumbar and sacral plexus anatomy, femoral, sciatic, and truncal nerve distributions. Anatomic foundation for lower extremity blocks and fascial plane techniques.

topic_domains.title: Vascular Access Anatomy
topic_domains.definition: Arterial and venous anatomy for radial, femoral, and central venous catheterization. Ultrasound correlation, anatomic variations, and structures at risk during vascular access.

topic_domains.title: Thoracic and Mediastinal Anatomy
topic_domains.definition: Heart, great vessels, lungs, and pleural spaces relevant to thoracic anesthesia and line placement. Anatomic considerations for thoracic surgery and one-lung ventilation.

branches.title: Chemistry and Physics Principles
branches.definition: Gas laws, fluid dynamics, electrical principles, solubility, diffusion, and physical chemistry underlying anesthesia machine function, drug delivery, and physiologic monitoring. The scientific basis for understanding equipment behavior and drug distribution.
branches.lens: Physical science foundation for equipment operation and drug behavior prediction

topic_domains.title: Gas Laws and Behavior
topic_domains.definition: Boyle's, Charles's, Dalton's, and Henry's laws as applied to anesthesia. Understanding gas behavior in cylinders, breathing circuits, and alveolar gas exchange.

topic_domains.title: Vaporizer Physics and Vapor Pressure
topic_domains.definition: Saturated vapor pressure, vaporizer design principles, temperature compensation, and altitude effects. Physics underlying accurate volatile anesthetic delivery.

topic_domains.title: Fluid Dynamics and Flow Principles
topic_domains.definition: Laminar and turbulent flow, Poiseuille's law, Bernoulli principle, and flow through orifices. Application to breathing circuits, airways, and IV fluid delivery.

topic_domains.title: Solubility, Diffusion, and Membrane Transport
topic_domains.definition: Blood-gas solubility coefficients, Fick's law of diffusion, and membrane permeability. Physical chemistry of anesthetic uptake, distribution, and elimination.

topic_domains.title: Electrical Principles and Safety
topic_domains.definition: Ohm's law, capacitance, grounding, microshock and macroshock hazards, and electrical safety in the OR. Understanding monitoring equipment function and patient electrical safety.

topic_domains.title: Pressure Measurement and Transduction
topic_domains.definition: Principles of pressure measurement, transducer function, natural frequency, damping, and zeroing. Physics underlying accurate invasive pressure monitoring.

sub_pillars.title: Clinical Equipment, Monitoring, and Technology
sub_pillars.definition: The clinical application, operation, and interpretation of anesthesia delivery systems, patient monitoring devices, airway equipment, and point-of-care technology at the bedside. This sub-pillar covers equipment use, troubleshooting, and output interpretation—distinct from procurement, maintenance, and IT infrastructure (Pillar 3).

branches.title: Anesthesia Delivery Systems
branches.definition: Clinical operation, function checking, and troubleshooting of anesthesia machines, vaporizers, breathing circuits, and mechanical ventilators. Encompasses the practical knowledge required to safely deliver anesthetic gases and provide ventilatory support.
branches.lens: Mastering the primary tools of anesthetic gas and ventilation delivery

topic_domains.title: Anesthesia Machine Components and Function
topic_domains.definition: Gas supply systems, flowmeters, pressure regulators, fail-safe mechanisms, and integrated workstation components. Understanding how the anesthesia machine receives, processes, and delivers fresh gas to the patient.

topic_domains.title: Breathing Circuits and Gas Delivery
topic_domains.definition: Circle system design, carbon dioxide absorption, Mapleson circuits, and fresh gas flow requirements. Clinical selection and operation of circuits for different patient populations and clinical scenarios.

topic_domains.title: Vaporizer Operation and Clinical Use
topic_domains.definition: Variable bypass and measured flow vaporizer operation, filling procedures, agent-specific considerations, and troubleshooting. Safe clinical use of modern vaporizers including desflurane heating systems.

topic_domains.title: Mechanical Ventilation Modes and Settings
topic_domains.definition: Volume-controlled, pressure-controlled, and pressure-support ventilation modes available on anesthesia machines. Setting tidal volume, respiratory rate, PEEP, I:E ratio, and interpreting ventilator graphics.

topic_domains.title: Machine Checkout and Safety Systems
topic_domains.definition: Pre-use checkout procedures, automated self-tests, leak testing, and verification of backup systems. Understanding oxygen failure protection, hypoxic guard systems, and pipeline-cylinder crossover.

topic_domains.title: Waste Gas Scavenging and Low-Flow Techniques
topic_domains.definition: Scavenging system components, occupational exposure limits, and environmental considerations. Clinical application of low-flow and minimal-flow anesthesia techniques for efficiency and reduced pollution.

branches.title: Physiologic Monitoring and Waveform Interpretation
branches.definition: Standard ASA monitors including pulse oximetry, capnography, ECG, and non-invasive blood pressure, plus waveform analysis, artifact recognition, and alarm management. The foundation of continuous patient assessment during anesthesia.
branches.lens: Continuous vigilance through monitoring data interpretation

topic_domains.title: Pulse Oximetry Technology and Limitations
topic_domains.definition: Principles of spectrophotometric oxygen saturation measurement, probe placement, motion artifact, and conditions affecting accuracy. Recognizing limitations including dyshemoglobinemias, low perfusion, and nail polish interference.

topic_domains.title: Capnography and Waveform Analysis
topic_domains.definition: End-tidal CO2 measurement principles, normal and abnormal capnogram morphology, and clinical interpretation. Using capnography for ventilation assessment, circuit integrity, and early detection of clinical changes.

topic_domains.title: Electrocardiographic Monitoring
topic_domains.definition: Lead placement, rhythm recognition, ST-segment monitoring, and artifact identification during anesthesia. Detecting ischemia, arrhythmias, and electrolyte abnormalities through continuous ECG surveillance.

topic_domains.title: Non-Invasive Blood Pressure Monitoring
topic_domains.definition: Oscillometric measurement principles, cuff sizing, measurement intervals, and sources of error. Understanding limitations in hypotension, arrhythmias, and when to transition to invasive monitoring.

topic_domains.title: Temperature Monitoring Methods
topic_domains.definition: Core versus peripheral temperature measurement sites, probe types, and accuracy considerations. Clinical selection of monitoring sites for different procedures and patient populations.

topic_domains.title: Depth of Anesthesia Monitoring
topic_domains.definition: Processed EEG technologies including BIS, entropy, and patient state index. Clinical application for titrating anesthetics, reducing awareness risk, and optimizing emergence.

topic_domains.title: Alarm Management and Clinical Integration
topic_domains.definition: Setting appropriate alarm limits, managing alarm fatigue, and prioritizing responses to multiple alarms. Integrating multiparameter data for comprehensive patient assessment.

branches.title: Advanced Hemodynamic and Neuromuscular Monitoring
branches.definition: Invasive pressure monitoring, cardiac output measurement, quantitative neuromuscular blockade assessment, and advanced physiologic parameters. Extends beyond standard monitoring for complex cases requiring precise hemodynamic or paralysis management.
branches.lens: Precision monitoring for high-acuity patient management

topic_domains.title: Arterial Line Monitoring and Waveform Analysis
topic_domains.definition: Arterial catheter placement indications, transducer setup, zeroing and leveling, and waveform interpretation. Recognizing overdamping, underdamping, and pathologic waveform variations.

topic_domains.title: Central Venous Pressure Monitoring
topic_domains.definition: Central venous catheter placement for pressure monitoring, waveform components, and clinical interpretation. Understanding CVP limitations and appropriate clinical applications.

topic_domains.title: Cardiac Output Monitoring Technologies
topic_domains.definition: Thermodilution, pulse contour analysis, esophageal Doppler, and non-invasive cardiac output methods. Selecting appropriate technology and interpreting results for goal-directed therapy.

topic_domains.title: Dynamic Fluid Responsiveness Parameters
topic_domains.definition: Stroke volume variation, pulse pressure variation, and passive leg raise testing. Using dynamic parameters to guide fluid resuscitation and predict volume responsiveness.

topic_domains.title: Quantitative Neuromuscular Monitoring
topic_domains.definition: Train-of-four monitoring, post-tetanic count, acceleromyography and electromyography devices. Meeting current guidelines for objective neuromuscular assessment before extubation (TOF ratio ≥0.9).

topic_domains.title: Transesophageal Echocardiography Basics
topic_domains.definition: Basic TEE probe insertion, standard views, and fundamental assessments for the non-cardiologist. Using TEE for intraoperative volume assessment, ventricular function, and valve evaluation.

branches.title: Airway Management Equipment
branches.definition: Direct and video laryngoscopes, supraglottic airways, endotracheal tubes, difficult airway adjuncts, and rescue devices. Clinical selection, use, and troubleshooting of the tools required for airway control.
branches.lens: Equipment mastery for airway security across all scenarios

topic_domains.title: Direct Laryngoscopy Equipment
topic_domains.definition: Macintosh and Miller blade designs, handle types, sizing considerations, and optimization techniques. Proper assembly, light verification, and troubleshooting of direct laryngoscopy equipment.

topic_domains.title: Video Laryngoscopy Systems
topic_domains.definition: Channeled versus non-channeled video laryngoscopes, device-specific techniques, and clinical selection. GlideScope, C-MAC, McGrath, and other platforms with their advantages and limitations.

topic_domains.title: Supraglottic Airway Devices
topic_domains.definition: LMA designs (classic, ProSeal, Supreme, i-gel), sizing, insertion techniques, and clinical applications. Understanding seal pressures, gastric access, and appropriate patient selection.

topic_domains.title: Endotracheal Tubes and Specialty Airways
topic_domains.definition: Standard ETT design, cuff management, sizing for adults and children, and specialty tubes (RAE, reinforced, double-lumen, laser-safe). Selection and management for specific surgical requirements.

topic_domains.title: Difficult Airway Adjuncts and Rescue Devices
topic_domains.definition: Bougies, stylets, airway exchange catheters, and optical stylets. Equipment for cannot-intubate-cannot-oxygenate scenarios including cricothyrotomy kits and jet ventilation systems.

topic_domains.title: Flexible Bronchoscopy Equipment
topic_domains.definition: Fiberoptic and video bronchoscope operation, setup, and maintenance. Equipment preparation for awake and asleep intubation, double-lumen tube positioning, and airway examination.

branches.title: Point-of-Care Diagnostic Technology
branches.definition: Bedside ultrasound (POCUS), blood gas analyzers, coagulation testing, glucose monitoring, and rapid diagnostic devices. Real-time diagnostic capabilities that inform immediate clinical decisions.
branches.lens: Immediate diagnostic information for time-critical decisions

topic_domains.title: Point-of-Care Ultrasound Fundamentals
topic_domains.definition: Basic ultrasound physics for clinical use, probe selection, image optimization, and machine operation. Foundation for vascular access, nerve identification, and focused diagnostic assessments.

topic_domains.title: Arterial Blood Gas Analysis
topic_domains.definition: Blood gas analyzer operation, sample handling, and result interpretation. Understanding pH, gas tensions, base excess, lactate, and electrolyte values for clinical decision-making.

topic_domains.title: Viscoelastic Coagulation Testing
topic_domains.definition: TEG and ROTEM technology, test parameters, and result interpretation. Using point-of-care coagulation analysis to guide transfusion and coagulation factor replacement.

topic_domains.title: Point-of-Care Hemoglobin and Glucose Monitoring
topic_domains.definition: Non-invasive and minimally invasive hemoglobin measurement devices and glucose meters. Understanding accuracy limitations and clinical application for intraoperative management.

topic_domains.title: Focused Cardiac and Pulmonary Ultrasound
topic_domains.definition: Basic transthoracic cardiac views, lung ultrasound for pneumothorax and pulmonary edema, and IVC assessment. Rapid bedside assessment for hemodynamic and respiratory evaluation.

sub_pillars.title: Perioperative Care and Anesthesia Techniques
sub_pillars.definition: The continuum of patient care from preoperative assessment through intraoperative management to postoperative recovery, encompassing all anesthesia delivery methods and modalities. Includes general anesthesia, regional anesthesia, monitored anesthesia care, airway management, enhanced recovery protocols, multimodal analgesia, patient safety practices, and crisis management.

branches.title: Preoperative Assessment and Optimization
branches.definition: Comprehensive patient evaluation, risk stratification, NPO guidelines, premedication strategies, and perioperative optimization. The foundation of safe anesthesia planning based on patient-specific factors.
branches.lens: Preparation and planning to minimize perioperative risk

branches.title: Airway Management Techniques
branches.definition: Airway assessment, basic and advanced airway techniques, difficult airway algorithms, and extubation strategies. The clinical skills and decision-making required to establish and maintain airway control.
branches.lens: Securing and maintaining the airway across all patient presentations

branches.title: General Anesthesia Delivery
branches.definition: Induction techniques, maintenance strategies (inhalational, TIVA, balanced), depth of anesthesia management, and emergence. The core techniques for rendering patients unconscious and managing the anesthetic state.
branches.lens: Mastering the art and science of general anesthesia

branches.title: Regional Anesthesia and Acute Pain Management
branches.definition: Neuraxial techniques, peripheral nerve blocks, multimodal analgesia strategies, and ERAS protocol integration. Techniques that provide surgical anesthesia, supplement general anesthesia, or manage acute postoperative pain.
branches.lens: Regional techniques and multimodal strategies for anesthesia and analgesia

branches.title: Sedation and Monitored Anesthesia Care
branches.definition: MAC techniques, procedural sedation, the sedation continuum, and patient selection for non-general anesthesia approaches. Managing patient comfort and safety without full general anesthesia.
branches.lens: Tailored sedation for procedures not requiring general anesthesia

branches.title: Intraoperative Physiologic Management
branches.definition: Hemodynamic optimization, ventilation strategies, fluid and blood product therapy, temperature management, and surgical positioning considerations. Maintaining physiologic homeostasis throughout the surgical procedure.
branches.lens: Moment-to-moment physiologic optimization during surgery

branches.title: Postoperative Care and PACU Management
branches.definition: Emergence management, PONV prophylaxis and treatment, postoperative pain control, discharge criteria, and handoff communication. Ensuring safe transition from anesthesia through recovery.
branches.lens: Safe recovery and transition from anesthetic care

branches.title: Patient Safety and Crisis Management
branches.definition: Emergency protocols, ACLS integration, malignant hyperthermia, local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), anaphylaxis, and medication safety practices. Recognition and management of life-threatening perioperative events.
branches.lens: Preparedness and response for perioperative emergencies

sub_pillars.title: Specialty Anesthesia and Special Populations
sub_pillars.definition: Population-specific and procedure-specific anesthesia care requiring specialized knowledge beyond general principles. Covers pediatric, obstetric, cardiac, neuroanesthesia, geriatric, trauma, and other subspecialty domains, as well as distinct care environments including ambulatory surgery centers and non-operating room anesthesia (NORA) locations.

branches.title: Pediatric Anesthesia
branches.definition: Anesthesia care for neonates, infants, children, and adolescents including developmental pharmacology, weight-based dosing, pediatric airway management, and age-specific considerations. Specialized knowledge for patients from birth through adolescence.
branches.lens: Adapting anesthesia practice across pediatric developmental stages

branches.title: Obstetric Anesthesia
branches.definition: Labor analgesia, cesarean delivery anesthesia, high-risk obstetric management, and maternal-fetal physiologic considerations. Care for the pregnant patient balancing maternal safety and fetal wellbeing.
branches.lens: Dual patient care balancing maternal and fetal considerations

branches.title: Cardiac, Vascular, and Thoracic Anesthesia
branches.definition: Anesthesia for cardiac surgery, major vascular procedures, and thoracic surgery including one-lung ventilation, cardiopulmonary bypass considerations, and advanced hemodynamic management.
branches.lens: High-acuity cardiovascular and thoracic surgical support

branches.title: Neuroanesthesia
branches.definition: Anesthesia for craniotomy, spine surgery, and neurointerventional procedures including cerebral physiology, intracranial pressure management, and neurophysiologic monitoring considerations.
branches.lens: Protecting and optimizing the central nervous system during surgery

branches.title: Geriatric, Trauma, and High-Acuity Patient Care
branches.definition: Anesthesia for elderly patients with age-related physiologic changes, trauma resuscitation and emergency surgery, and management of critically ill or medically complex patients.
branches.lens: Adapting care for vulnerable and physiologically compromised patients

branches.title: Ambulatory Surgery and Non-Operating Room Anesthesia
branches.definition: Anesthesia in ambulatory surgery centers, office-based settings, and NORA locations including endoscopy, interventional radiology, cardiac catheterization, and MRI suites. Unique considerations for care outside traditional operating rooms.
branches.lens: Safe anesthesia delivery in diverse and remote care environments
